text.p: These are some of the leading stories in the official Vietnamese press on Thursday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
-- Communist Party Chief Do Muoi has said greater efforts are needed to improve the national education system, which has deteriorated since the Vietnam war ended in 1975.
-- Foreign Minister Nguyen Manh Cam has met with U.S. Secretary of State Warren Christopher and National Security Adviser Anthony Lake to exchange views on improving economic and commercial ties.
-- Vietnam will levy an infrastructure tax on urban construction projects from next year, the Ministry of Finance has announced. - - - -
-- Vietnam's garment exports to the European Union reached $285 million in the first nine months of 1996. Total garment exports this year are expected to reach about $1 billion.
-- Visiting foreign military ships will be required to respect Vietnam's sovereignty and independence and comply with Vietnamese law, under new government regulations.

-- Communist Party Secretary Do Muoi has concluded a tour of central and southern provinces to prepare for the Party Central Committee's second plenum on education, training, science and technology. - - - -
-- Vietnam sold 70 billion ($6.35 million) worth of one-year Treasury notes with an annual coupon of 8.0 percent at an auction on Wednesday. - - - -
-- Prime Minister Vo Van Kiet has issued a decision tightening controls on non-state enterprises and service companies.
-- Hanoi has launched an anti-drugs campaign in its schools. - - - -
